articles.headline: Stanford Sentenced to 110-Year Term in $7 Billion Ponzi Case
articles.snippet: A federal jury in March convicted R. Allen Stanford of 13 out of 14 counts of fraud in connection with a worldwide scheme over more than two decades.
articles.abstract: A federal jury in March convicted R. Allen Stanford of 13 out of 14 counts of fraud in connection with a worldwide scheme over more than two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Jaime Escalona was fleeced so thoroughly by the financier R. Allen Stanford that he could no longer pay for his grandson’s autism treatments, he said in a steady voice in court on Thursday, before turning to the defendant and declaring, “You are a dirty, rotten scoundrel.”

articles.headline: Airports Focus on the Ground
articles.snippet: The need to accommodate bigger airplanes and a growing number of foreign carriers has helped spur many of the new investments.
articles.abstract: The need to accommodate bigger airplanes and a growing number of foreign carriers has helped spur many of the new investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time when federal and state public works programs are stalled, the nation’s biggest airports are in the midst of major renovations or expansions that, taken together, amount to some of the largest infrastructure projects in the country.

articles.headline: Europe Braces for Greek Vote — and Maybe More
articles.snippet: Greek elections on Sunday could soon bring real-world urgency to a debate that had been largely academic: Whether the euro zone can withstand the departure of one of its members.
articles.abstract: Greek elections on Sunday could soon bring real-world urgency to a debate that had been largely academic: Whether the euro zone can withstand the departure of one of its members.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Greek elections on Sunday could bring urgency to a debate that has been largely academic: whether the euro zone can withstand the departure of one of its members.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Paul Geitner

articles.headline: Switzerland and Britain Gird Against the Storm
articles.snippet: The two largest European economies that do not use the euro announced measures to help shelter their countries from the debt crisis that has engulfed Greece and Spain.
articles.abstract: The two largest European economies that do not use the euro announced measures to help shelter their countries from the debt crisis that has engulfed Greece and Spain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The two largest European economies that do not use the euro announced measures on Thursday to help shelter their countries from a crisis that has engulfed Greece and Spain and appears poised to sweep over Italy.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and David Jolly

articles.headline: As Europe’s Currency Union Frays, Conspiracy Theories Fly
articles.snippet: The roots of the current euro crisis lie in events 20 years ago, when an experiment with semi-fixed exchange rates broke down under pressure from German monetary policy.
articles.abstract: The roots of the current euro crisis lie in events 20 years ago, when an experiment with semi-fixed exchange rates broke down under pressure from German monetary policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We need not just a currency union; we also need a so-called fiscal union, more common budget policies. And we need above all a political union. That means that we must, step by step as things go forward, give up  more powers to Europe as well and allow Europe oversight possibilities.”

articles.headline: Egypt’s Disarray Puts a Regional Investment Bank in Play
articles.snippet: EFG-Hermes, struggling in a volatile market, scrambles to sell a large piece of its business to a smaller rival in Qatar.
articles.abstract: EFG-Hermes, struggling in a volatile market, scrambles to sell a large piece of its business to a smaller rival in Qatar.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Yasser el-Mallawany and Hassan Heikal are accustomed to turmoil. In recent years, they have steered EFG-Hermes through political upheaval, economic pain and market volatility, transforming the Egyptian financial firm into the leading investment bank in the Arab world.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Sara Hamdan

articles.headline: In the Facebook Era, Reminders of Loss After Families Fracture
articles.snippet: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and other social media can add to the pain of family estrangements because they provide a peek into private lives and a reminder of what has been lost.
articles.abstract: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and other social media can add to the pain of family estrangements because they provide a peek into private lives and a reminder of what has been lost.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, estrangements between family members, for all the anguish they can cause, could mean a fairly clean break. People would cut off contact, never to be heard from again unless they reconciled.

articles.headline: Accused Chinese Party Members Face Harsh Discipline
articles.snippet: Communist Party members suspected of corruption in China often vanish into an extrajudicial disciplinary system, called “shuanggui,” where they face torture and enforced confessions.
articles.abstract: Communist Party members suspected of corruption in China often vanish into an extrajudicial disciplinary system, called “shuanggui,” where they face torture and enforced confessions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Membership in the Chinese Communist Party has many advantages. Officials often enjoy government-issued cars, bottomless expense accounts and the earning potential from belonging to a club whose members control every lever of government and many of the nation’s most lucrative enterprises.

articles.headline: Revolt Leaders Cite Failure to Uproot Old Order in Egypt
articles.snippet: The liberals, leftists and Islamists who orchestrated Egypt’s revolution say they realize they failed to displace the networks of power that Hosni Mubarak nurtured over decades.
articles.abstract: The liberals, leftists and Islamists who orchestrated Egypt’s revolution say they realize they failed to displace the networks of power that Hosni Mubarak nurtured over decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — They toppled a pharaoh, but now the small circle of liberals, leftists and Islamists who orchestrated Egypt’s revolution say they realize they failed to uproot the networks of power that Hosni Mubarak nurtured for nearly three decades.

articles.headline: Central Banks Stand at Ready to Fortify Euro
articles.snippet: The days after Greece’s elections are seen as a turning point that could determine whether Europe’s fiscal ties grow closer or fray.
articles.abstract: The days after Greece’s elections are seen as a turning point that could determine whether Europe’s fiscal ties grow closer or fray.
articles.lead_paragraph: With an election looming in Greece that could determine the future of the euro, central bankers overseas signaled Friday that they were prepared to take action to shore up nervous financial markets after Sunday’s vote.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and David Jolly

articles.headline: On Eve of Vote, Egypt’s Military Extends Its Power
articles.snippet: Egypt’s military rulers moved to consolidate power before the presidential runoff election, shutting down the Islamist-led Parliament and seizing the sole right to issue laws.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s military rulers moved to consolidate power before the presidential runoff election, shutting down the Islamist-led Parliament and seizing the sole right to issue laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers moved to consolidate power Friday on the eve of the presidential runoff election, shutting down the Islamist-led Parliament, locking out lawmakers and seizing the sole right to issue laws even after a new head of state takes office.

articles.headline: Obama to Permit Young Migrants to Remain in U.S.
articles.snippet: President Obama outlined a new immigration policy under which young illegal immigrants who came to the country as children can obtain work permits and will not face deportation.
articles.abstract: President Obama outlined a new immigration policy under which young illegal immigrants who came to the country as children can obtain work permits and will not face deportation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children will be allowed to remain in the country without fear of deportation and able to work, under an executive action the Obama administration announced on Friday.
articles.byline: By Julia Preston and John H. Cushman Jr

articles.headline: German Rectitude Has Its Risks
articles.snippet: Berlin’s reluctance to aid its euro zone brethren has many supporters, but saying “no” too many times could have global repercussions.
articles.abstract: Berlin’s reluctance to aid its euro zone brethren has many supporters, but saying “no” too many times could have global repercussions.
articles.lead_paragraph: As markets pummeled Spanish and Italian government bonds this week after Europe’s latest effort to contain the euro crisis, Germany seemed increasingly isolated in its demands for more austerity. The June 9 cover of The Economist portrayed the world economy as a sinking oil tanker with the caption, “Please can we start the engines now, Mrs. Merkel?”
